data: The text is arranged in a circular pattern on the fragment.

Iscrizioni greche archaiche di Sicilia e Magna Grecia. Iscrizioni di Sicilia. II. Iscrizioni di Gela e di Agrigento
Renato Arena, Iscrizioni greche archaiche di Sicilia e Magna Grecia. Iscrizioni di Sicilia. II. Iscrizioni di Gela e di Agrigento, 2nd ed., vol. 2, 5 voll. (Alessandria: Edizioni dell’Orso, 2002)
Inscriptions grecques dialectales de Sicile : contribution à l'étude du vocabulaire grec colonial
Laurent Dubois, Inscriptions grecques dialectales de Sicile : contribution à l’étude du vocabulaire grec colonial, CEFR 119 (Rome: Ecole française de Rome, 1989)
Le formule delle dediche votive nella Grecia arcaica
M.L. Lazzarini, Le Formule Delle Dediche Votive Nella Grecia Arcaica (Roma, 1976)
Lo scavo del Thesmophorion di Bitalemi e il culto delle divinità ctonie a Gela
P. Orlandini, ‘Lo Scavo Del Thesmophorion Di Bitalemi e Il Culto Delle Divinità Ctonie a Gela’, Kokalos 12 (1966): 8–35
hιαρὰ Θεσμοφόρο̄ ἐκ τᾶς Δικαιο͂ς σκᾱνᾶς

1hια̣ρ̣ὰ Θ̣ε̣σ̣μοφόρο̄
2ἐκ τᾶς Δικαιο͂ς σκᾱνᾶς

1HΙ..Α...ΜΟΦΟΡΟ̄
2ΕΚΤΑΣΔΙΚΑΙΟΣΣΚᾹΝΑΣ

Facsimile Images

Apparatus criticus

  • Text after Dubois (IGDS 1)

English translation

Valentina Mignosa

Dedicated to Thesmophoros by the skana of Dikaiô.

Italian translation

Valentina Mignosa

Dedicato a Thesmophoros da parte della skana di Dikaiô.

commentary

The fragment is part of a pyxis that was a votive offering for Thesmophoros. A Thesmophorion was would be found in Bitalemi (see Orlandini 1966). Of interest is the term σκανά, variously interpreted by editors. According to Orlandini, the term refers to the wooden building which served to house the women participating in the Thesmophoria, and whose base was found in mud bricks at Bitalemi. More plausible is the interpretation of Dubois (IGDS 1, no. 155), according to whom the term designates by metonymy the group of women, in this case under the direction of Dikaio, who took part in the Thesmoforia. The scholar in fact points out that in the regulation of Halaesa (no. 196, ll.39-46) the term σκανά designates a landmark in the territory, so it must have been a fairly solid building (however, it should be noted that even if this skana had been a wooden building, given its importance in the sacred landscape, it would still have been a landmark. Dubois again notes that in the sacred law of Elatea (LSCG no. 82 ), the verb σκᾱνε͂ν has the sense of θοινᾶσθαι "to take part in a ceremonial meal". So the group of women who took part in the Thesmophoria and conducted their ritual functions in this building, which was also used for ceremonial banquets, were perhaps designated - precisely by metonymy - by the name of the building itself, which would thus serve as a collective name in our text. The name of a woman Δικαιώ is also well attested: in Thessaly (IG 9.0156), Athens (IG 2.9064) and in Bouthrôtos in Epirus.

  • Arena 2002 46a, pl. XVII.2 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001373

  • Lazzarini 1976 586, p. 125 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10002517
  • Orlandini 1966 20-21, tab.10.4 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001464
  • Orlandini 1966 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001464
